column2: The inclusion–exclusion principle is a well-known property in probability theory, and is instrumental in some computational problems such as the evaluation of system reliability or the calculation of the probability of a Boolean formula in diagnosis
column3: However, in the setting of uncertainty theories more general than probability theory, this principle no longer holds in general
column4: It is therefore useful to know for which families of events it continues to hold
column5: This paper investigates this question in the setting of belief functions
column6: After exhibiting original sufficient and necessary conditions for the principle to hold, we illustrate its use on the uncertainty analysis of Boolean and non-Boolean systems in reliability.

column2: In the study, we propose a concept of incremental fuzzy models in which fuzzy rules are aimed at compensating discrepancies resulting because of the use of a certain global yet simple model of general nature (such as e.g., a constant or linear regression)
column3: The structure of input data and error discovered through fuzzy clustering is captured in the form of a collection of fuzzy clusters, which helps eliminate (compensate) error produced by the global model
column4: We discuss a detailed architecture of the proposed rule-based model and present its design based on an augmented version of Fuzzy C-Means (FCM)
column5: An extended suite of experimental studies offering some comparative analysis is covered as well.

column2: The possibility of linking paper to digital information is enhanced by recent developments in printed electronics
column3: In this article we report the design and evaluation of a local newspaper augmented with capacitive touch regions and an embedded Bluetooth chip working with an adjunct device
column4: These allowed the interactive playback of associated audio and the registration of manual voting actions on the web
column5: Design conventions inherited from paper and the web were explored by showing four different versions of an interactive newspaper to 16 community residents
column6: The diverse responses of residents are described, outlining the potential of the approach for local journalism and recommendations for the design of interactive newsprint.

column2: For many problem domains, such as medicine, chain graphs are more attractive than Bayesian networks as they support representing interactions between variables that have no natural direction
column3: In particular, interactions between variables that result from certain feedback mechanisms can be represented by chain graphs
column4: Using qualitative abstractions of probabilistic interactions is also of interest, as these allow focusing on patterns in the interactions rather than on the numerical detail
column5: Such patterns are often known by experts and sufficient for making decisions
column6: So far, qualitative abstractions of probabilistic interactions have only been developed for Bayesian networks in the form of qualitative probabilistic networks
column7: In this paper, such qualitative abstractions are developed for chain graphs with the practical aim of using qualitative knowledge as constraints on the hyperspace of probability distributions
column8: The usefulness of qualitative chain graphs is explored for modelling and reasoning about the interactions between diseases.

column2: A novel technique to classify time series with imprecise hidden Markov models is presented
column3: The learning of these models is achieved by coupling the EM algorithm with the imprecise Dirichlet model
column4: In the stationarity limit, each model corresponds to an imprecise mixture of Gaussian densities, this reducing the problem to the classification of static, imprecise-probabilistic, information
column5: Two classifiers, one based on the expected value of the mixture, the other on the Bhattacharyya distance between pairs of mixtures, are developed
column6: The computation of the bounds of these descriptors with respect to the imprecise quantification of the parameters is reduced to, respectively, linear and quadratic optimization tasks, and hence efficiently solved
column7: Classification is performed by extending the k-nearest neighbors approach to interval-valued data
column8: The classifiers are credal, meaning that multiple class labels can be returned in the output
column9: Experiments on benchmark datasets for computer vision show that these methods achieve the required robustness whilst outperforming other precise and imprecise methods.

column2: Body temperature is an important physiological indicator in the whole process of pig breeding
column3: Temperature measurement is also an effective means to assist in disease diagnosis and pig health monitoring
column4: In the conventional method of measuring body temperature, a mercury column is used to obtain the rectal temperature
column5: The operation of this method is complicated and requires a large amount of labor
column6: This kind of temperature measurement method is contact and can make the pig stressed, which is disadvantageous for the healthy growth of pigs
column7: Therefore, rectal temperature measurement no longer meets the needs of the large-scale pig industry in China's welfare agriculture
column8: In recent years, the emerging pig body temperature detection technologies are electronic temperature measurement technology, infrared temperature measurement technology and so on
column9: Infrared temperature measurement technology has been the main means of measuring the temperature of pig body surface with its advantages of non-contact, long distance and real-time
column10: At present, infrared temperature measurement technology and infrared image processing technology used in pig breeding are still in the exploration stage
column11: Nowadays, the infrared temperature measurement equipment based on point-by-point analysis represented by infrared thermometer and temperature measurement equipment based on full-field analysis represented by infrared thermal imager have been applied to pig breeding industry
column12: These types of temperature measurement are more in line with the needs of the pig breeding industry to transform and upgrade to the automation, in line with the development concept of welfare farming and smart agriculture, and its development prospects are very impressive.

column2: A number of proposals have been proposed for measuring inconsistency for knowledge bases
column3: However, it is rarely investigated how to incorporate preference information into inconsistency measures
column4: This paper presents two approaches to measuring inconsistency for stratified knowledge bases
column5: The first approach, termed the multi-section inconsistency measure (MSIM for short), provides a framework for characterizing the inconsistency at each stratum of a stratified knowledge base
column6: Two instances of MSIM are defined: the naive MSIM and the stratum-centric MSIM
column7: The second approach, termed the preference-based approach, aims to articulate the inconsistency in a stratified knowledge base from a global perspective
column8: This approach allows us to define measures by taking into account the number of formulas involved in inconsistencies as well as the preference levels of these formulas
column9: A set of desirable properties are introduced for inconsistency measures of stratified knowledge bases and studied with respect to the inconsistency measures introduced in the paper
column10: Computational complexity results for these measures are presented
column11: In addition, a simple but explanatory example is given to illustrate the application of the proposed approaches to requirements engineering.

column2: The scope of this paper is to present a novel gait methodology in order to obtain an efficient walking capability for an original walking free-leg hexapod structure (WalkingHex) of tri-radial symmetry
column3: Torque in the upper (actuated) spherical joints and stability margin analyses are obtained based on a constraint-driven gait generator
column4: Therefore, the kinematic information of foot pose and angular orientation of the platform are considered as important variables along with the effect that they can produce in different gait cycles
column5: The torque analysis is studied to determine the motor torque requirements for each step of the gait so that the robotic structure yields a stable and achievable pose
column6: In this way, the analysis of torque permits the selection of an optimal gait based on stability margin criteria
column7: Consequently, a gait generating algorithm is proposed for different types of terrain such as flat, ramp or stepped surfaces.

column2: Elicited physiological affect in humans collaborating with their robot partners was investigated to determine its influence on decision-making performance in serious games
column3: A turn-taking version of the Tower of Hanoi game was used, where physiological arousal and valence underlying such human-robot proximate collaboration were investigated
column4: A comparable decision performance in the serious game was found between human and non-humanoid robot arm collaborator conditions, while higher physiological affect was found in humans collaborating with such robot collaborators
column5: It is suggested that serious games which are carefully designed to take into consideration the elicited physiological arousal might witness a better decision-making performance and more positive valence using non-humanoid robot partners instead of human ones.

column2: Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) have many applications in density estimation and data clustering
column3:
However, the models do not adapt well to curved and strongly nonlinear data, since many Gaussian components are typically needed to appropriately fit the data that lie around the nonlinear manifold.
                  To solve this problem we constructed the Active Function Cross-Entropy Clustering (afCEC) method, which uses Gaussians in curvilinear coordinate systems
column4:
The method has a few advantages in relation to GMM: it enables easy adaptation to clustering of complicated data sets along with a predefined family of functions and does not need external methods to determine the number of clusters, as it automatically (on-line) reduces the number of groups.
                  Experiments on synthetic data, Chinese characters, data from UCI repository and wind turbine monitoring systems show that the proposed nonlinear model typically obtains better results than the classical methods.
